content:
Posted: July 10, 2014
												Okay, so after finally pouring 100 hours into this game in such a small time, I've decided to actually write a review on this game now. This review is rather lengthly. Sorry for being boring.This is not a pay to win.First off, the description for this game is outdated. It is not updated weekly, and has been 'abandoned' by the developers. There has not been an update since early 2013. Uber Entertainment said multiple times on their forums that if they have a small chance to revive the game, they will. For now, they shall focus on bigger projects. Let's hope they keep that promise. Now to the review.After acquiring over 100 hours, I can say this game is PURE HELL to get into. The game has been 'dead' or rather, has a low playerbase, and has done for about 2 years now. There are the occasional new players, but they don't stick around after what they find.The BadSo, before you decide whether or not to play this game, or dive in blind and think 'Yeah! This'll be great and fun!' I'm going to post all the negatives so you don't have to experience them getting thrown at your face first hand.1. The CommunityAs I have previously stated, the playerbase for this game is rather at a low. Due to this factor, you'll find most players you run into will be fully geared to the teeth (completely cosmetics.. except for endorsements, but we'll get to that). Now, I'm not saying every experienced player in this game is a huge butt, but most of them are.You'll find people will find ways to get angry in almost any situation. Whether their team is winning or losing. They'll find ways to insult you, no matter how. Be it your interests, name, how you type/play. You name it.I'll probably go as far to say the community on this game is worse than Dota 2 or League of Legends. However, this doesn't mean you can find... "nice" players to run into. I can name a few, but I won't mention any names in this review to respect people's privacy.2. EndorsementsOkay, so. Endorsements! I'll give you a quick run down on what they are.In SMNC, you start off at level 0. Every 4 levels, you unlock a new Endorsement slot, getting up to 25 slots in total. You can go above the level 100 mark, but this will not unlock any endorsement slots.Now, Endorsements themselves are small buffs with a positive advantage, and a negative disadvantage. These can be bought with coins, and are permenant, so you can buy and keep as many as you like. Mixing and matching different Endorsements at level 100 can help in giving you a huge advantage against players.Now, here's the thing.As I have previously explained, playerbase is rather low. So you'll be finding if you're a new player straight off the bat, you'll be running into all these powerful and experienced pros... With all of their Endorsement slots filled.This feature alone is probably one of the single handed reasons along with the community that I hate this game.3. MatchmakingNow, this is what I feel to be one of the game's biggest flaws.As explained above, most of the community is experienced players. Now, if you get new players joining, or less experienced ones, this won't change anything. Matchmaking is COMPLETELY random. It won't pair you up against players based on their level/skill/endorsement sets, it'll just drag and drop you into a list and not care.This leads to cases such as having a completely new team, fight against a team of experienced players.. Utterly getting slaughtered in the process.4. Conclusion of Bad PointsAs you may have guessed just by reading this...This game is incredibly hard to get into. To the point of masochism. It's easy to get stressed out over the various negatives at this game.Now, you may be wondering... Why did I go through with it? Why did I continue to play, despite the horrible negatives?The GoodI can't deny it. This game is special. Something is so fun and quirky about it.1. The Atmosphere. I'll get this out of the way first.Simply put, this game has an amazing atmosphere. A futuristic combat sport set in an arena, crowd going wild, announcers with funny voice lines, fitting situations well. What's not to love?The Crowd is dynamic. Say if you were to make a kill, make something happen, or an event happens in the map, the crowd will respond. Being either cheers of joy, or jeers of disappoint.The Announcers are fun to listen to. They sometimes share interesting stories, talk about what is happening in the match, and will respond to any kills/killstreaks/annihilator use. It all feels so real, and well done. The voice acting is great in this game. That is undeniable.2. Gameplay itselfMost people end up mistaking this game for a third person shooter... and end up raging in the process.Though it may feel strange or possibly even unnatural at first, SMNC has a really great feel once you get the hang of it. A MOBA with Third Person Shooter hybrid elements? At the time, it was pretty new. Fresh, too. I'm not sure if there have been any since.Each pro has three abilities, all bound to SHIFT, Q and E by default. It's simple, really. Each pro is easy to understand, and there are many to choose from.. Although there are no longer 'free pro rotations'. I've had fun playing a lot of them though!All in all, I feel like this is one of those games where you have to 'play it yourself to understand' it.3. Conclusion of Good PointsI honestly don't think I really need much of a conclusion here, as most of it is explained above. I can give a bit of advice though.You can't learn if you don't play, so keep on trying! And play for fun. Ignore the occasional butthead you might come across who will call you a 'feeder' or a 'noob' or anything of the sort.And that concludes my Super Monday Night Combat Review! If you've read this far, I'm amazed. Thank you for reading, as I appreciate it. Sorry if I might've bored you though. Have fun playing! I hope

Posted: October 9, 2014
												I wanted to enjoy SMNC back when it actually had people. I couldn't though for the same reasons that's driving new players away today.There are two reasons. The first being the complete lack of matchmaking via skill/experience. This should have been priority for an MOBA where extreme teamwork is important. Match the players who were new with the other players who were new and the more experienced against the more experienced! This should have just been common sense. Uber did not make this a priority and SMNC lost a lot of the players who would have been really interested in this game when it first came on steam.The other reason I stopped playing was because of the pile of dogshit this game calls a community and the fact that I hear it's gotten worse as the game dwindled down to a small one tells me that the absolute death of SMNC is imminent.You would think that the small veteran community nowadays would band together, grow up, and attempt to build the playerbase by ACTUALLY BEING PLEASENT TO PLAY WITH, but no. Let's all be a bunch of angry ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥s and dig the hole a bit deeper with every single match until there is literally no one who wants to play this game.The terrible matchmaking early on wasn't enough to make me stop playing, but the horrible attitudes of the community along with it was enough to make me uninstall. So congrats there, veteran community. You keep driving away any chance of this game making a comeback because you can't stop being♥♥♥♥♥♥♥to the new players (and eachother) who might have actually enjoyed this game all because you want to, "win".Well congrats! "Your winner"! What's the prize? AN EMPTY GAME TO GO WITH YOUR INFERIORITY COMPLEX!+1 for getting the Big Rigs reference.

content:
Posted: February 14, 2015
												Don't let the lack of players stop you from playing this game. Yes it is true, the community is mostly dead and those who are still here are way better than you are. Play it anyway. I'll explain why, and then I will explain how.Why should you play SMNC even though it has no population and you will get spanked:The SuperCrossfire mode came out in spring of 2012 and there is still nothing like it. SuperCrossfire is intense, and will make you incredibly angry, but it is the most satisfying game I have ever player. Don't play SuperCrossfire, PLAY TURBOCROSS. When you see these reviews saying that they can't get into matches, or get into them infrequently, they are talking about SuperCrossfire which requires a full team before the match begins. In a perfect world, we could play that mode, but the world sucks so we have to play TurboCross. Even though TurboCross is watered down SuperCrossfire, it still has no equivalent. Believe me, if I could find a third-person shooter MOBA with jumping, dodging, grapples, and class-synergy, then I would be playing it instead (assuming that more people played it). Here is the low-down, Uber spent millions on this game and it shows. Unfortunately, they didn't make money from it so it has been abandoned. But again, there just isn't anything like it and what it does is amazing.The basic idea is that you and your team are supposed to help your bots advance in two lanes in order to take down the shields of enemy turrets and eventually take down the money-ball. There are two lanes, so even though you may be pushing one really hard, you have to worry about how the other is doing. All of the maps are symetrical. Now, a lot of players just don't understand how important it is to kill bots. Killing bots is the most effective method of winning the game. Of course the other team will try to kill you while you do it, and you don't want that to happen. Why don't you want that to happen? because while you are dead, you kill less bots. Kill bots, push your lane, take out their turrets once the shield is down, do the same to the money ball. If you see that the other lane is having the same done to it by the other team, switch lanes and push it back to atleast the middle. Oh I forgot to explain why this is fun. It's amazing. When you and 1-3 other teammates are pushing a lane together and you make progress even though the other team is trying to kill you, you feel like you are making something happen. This is a different feeling than coming in first in a race or having a high kill-to-death ratio. Pushing a lane is slow and must me sustained. When I die, I worry about how far back my lane is going to get pushed and whether or not we will be able to push it back to where it was. It's different than k/d, it just is. Other third-person shooters just don't offer this. How to play with a low population:Play a Pickup game of Turbocross on the North American server after 5pm EST preferably on the weekend. Yes, I know that this is limiting, but it's what you have to do to play this game that no one else has made yet and is ahead of its time. It will take maybe 10 minutes to find your first game, but after that you are in rhythm, so most of the players of your last game will show up for the next. You will see the same names on different days, there are not many of us. Be nice because you will see them again. They will not be nice to you, I am sorry. Stay near your team and kill-bots. Stay on one lane until you know the maps. Eventually you should ask someone what the annihilator is. Good luck. If people knew what this game was like, there would be a lot of people playing it, but it looks like Team Fortress 2 and when it don't play in a similar way, folks think it is a bad game. SMNC has major flaws, but there just isn't anything like it and what it does is valuable.

												2 Years after this game being abandoned by the Devs, people still play it AND there's no game like SMNC, it's a one of a kind game that needs to be known more.The game can't really be dead, because there's people like myself who don't want to let this game go, it's a really special flower that won't ever die.Besides the low population, what else does this game offer, quite a lot actually!Pros:Lots of pros! (Heros) all of them bring unquie styles of gameplay, like the quick moving Assassin, to the grapple monster Veteran, to the beatboxing Robo Hobo, to the charging Tank, to the bot pushing Leo and a lot more!Like I mentioned, this game is one of a kind, a 3rd person shooter MOBA with lots of bots you can spawn, like Fuji bots, Bouncers and the Jackbot.The commentators are some of the best in gaming, both feel genuine and are so much fun to listen to, I never get tired of thier lines, despite listening to them over a thousand times.A lot of music! From hawaiian music, rock and roll, digital music, banjos and a lot more!Mascots who give you bonus items! Like Bullseye gives you money, churros and Bacon! Juicebot who gives you fruit which fills up your juice meter! And Chicky Cantor who gives you a huge boost when you defeat him.You can get some free items and boosters! You can connect your Facebook profile to SMNC and get a free assault kit! Which includes the FIreball set, 2 taunts and I think a booster too! There's also a guide which gives codes for boosters too!


super mnc store codes (xp/coin boosts) 
A Guide for Super Monday Night Combat
By: snot

			helo		


Unquie looking maps!Has a unquie sporty feel that no other game has created so far.Voice acting is really good and the personality of the characters are great! (Except Gunslinger who is boring and Combat Girl who is just a Sterotype and boobs)Cons:The low population  (Like I mentioned) and the only gamemodes you will be able to play is Turbocross and Blitz, Supercross is 100% dead, you have a higher chance to win the lottery then to find a Supercross match, Blitz is also hard to find matches, speak with players in the chat and see if they want to play, also the most common players you will come across play this game a lot and stomp games over and over, or new players who have no clue what to do... speaking of which...Very steep learning curve, this game is hard to learn due to the lack of a good tutorial, there is one called Training Camp, but you don't learn anything major, like Products, Endorsments, which pros are more deadly or HOW IMPORTANT IT IS TO KILL BOTS!(Judging by Turbocross since Super is dead) The balance is all over the place, all the heros (Except Leo and the Veteran) have something OP in them, from Gunner's rocket, Tank's Grenades and charges, Karl's burst, Gunslinger's r*t*rded DPS, Support's Airstrikes, Combat Girl's and Megabeth's.... EVERYTHING! There is at least one OP thing about most Pros, and you will notice them quickly.Do not buy any items, you can unbox most of them thanks to a glitch, if you use a key on a chest/crate/treasure ball, the key doesn't disappear, meaning you can get thousands of rare items.The community is bad, mostly filled with as*h*les who complain and b**ch about everything, there are nice people, like when I came back to this game, a friend gave me some items! Thanks again!Small amount of maps, there's Gun Mountain, Loco Moco, Bullet Gorge, Downtown Spunky, Grenade Arena (My fav,) the Training Camp, and the Blitz map, the normal maps have tons of exploits of them, like Downtown Spunky Megabeth can rocket jump onto a building and attack all the turrets below, Loco Moco's mid can be spammed by Sniper pros and Supports, you can attack the money ball UNDER the map with Assault on Grenade Arena and more. Plus Gun Mountain is the worst map in the game, for $750 you can activate Shelly, aka clear a lane with no effort.The Devs are very shady, while they said they cannot update this game due to the lack of funding, they went on to kickstarter and got their next game funded called Planetary Annihilation, during 2014 they attempted to fund another game called Human Resources, however Planetary Annihilation wasn't close to being finished as it was missing promises from the Kickstarter, which was one of the biggest reasons why Human Resources fell, addtionally they ditched the orignal MNC IN THE SAME YEAR IT WAS RELEASED ON STEAM FOR THIS GAME! As of right now they have pretty much been silent with MNC franchise, just a word of warning when you buy some of their products as they aren't trustworthee, sorry Uber but you lost A LOT of trust with A LOT of customers.Overall this game is one of a kind, lots of upsides and downsides, and I can understand why you don't enjoy this, but give this game a chance, hard to learn, but a lot of fun in the end.If you want to see the current population check the link below.http://steamcharts.com/app/104700

content:
Posted: December 26, 2013
												Its dead jim, but seriously it was good at one point then the devs decided not to update the game anymore. The Good1. Maps are pretty good and well designed (with supercross in mind) 2. Character balance for the most part is alright3. Good skill ceilingThe Bad1. Small playerbase that is divided by 3 seperate game modes (try dividing 50 players into supercross, turbocross, and blitz)2. Supercross thier bread and butter of the game is dead. Why is this bad you may ask, its because all of the maps, characters, and even products are balanced around this gamemode. (hell even the bots are balanaced for supercross)3. The team comp in higher level play will allways have a assault simply because he deals high damage from a far range, can chase and the sky is the limit for him. His jetpack recharges rediculously fast and it can be angled to go higher then intended by  charging into ramps or by granade jumping. Using the jetpack has no set backs for assault, no aiming penalty like in the first game. TL;DR Assault is OP. 4. Massive Air is still a broken product that they haven't fixed even though it was reported months ago. To put it simply it turns a bad player into a mediocoure one, by speeding them up (which was unintended) and making them harder to grapple (another unintended side effect). To people that don't know what Massive Air is its one of the products in the game that was only intended to give you better jump control. 5. While I'm on the subject of products most of the products in the game are useless. A product to the people that never played this game are passives which activate on certian conditions and even only activate on certain levels. (example parting gift, it activates from level 1 and on and only activates on your death, it heals your team for 350 health and scales with the teamates level) You will only see the products money magnet, juicy spunky, and over armor being used in this game in higher level play or Massive Air for the above reason. Any other product is seldomly used.6. If you took a look at the chowder (beta builds for SMNC) forums, the devs never really listioned to the people who were trying to balance the game, they instead opted to make more characters and more gamemodes instead of fixing the pressing problems in the game which I listed some above. (also one of the devs got wrecked in a beta scrim and opted to nerf veteren out of spite and not game balance)7. The community has divided into two parts, super try hards and people who just wanna have fun, the sad part is the latter part of the community for the most part is dying off or going to other games. Really don't bother unless your are decient at the game which can only happen if you managed to play it before supercross died off for good.8. This is probiblly the killer of the game but doesnt apply anymore since the ques for supercross are dead but still could bring to light why supercross is dead. At level 0-20 when you first get the game you are put into ques with people of your own skill level (aka a newbie camp) so you dont have to worry about vets stomping you. The moment you reached level 21 you are put into the general que and many many people would get stomped, causing them to quit the game because they weren't ready. 9. The in game voice chat is dead, and has been dead for over a year now. (stopped working Novemember 2012) The devs still didn't fix this issue.10. The game hasn't been patched for almost a year from me writing this review even though they got a volunteer to fix the bugs in the game (apperently they messed up the coding really really really badly in unreal 3) said bug fixes from the volunteer never got into SMNC, and the only person who was working on the bug fixes got reassigned to work on thier other game Planetary Anhilation.11. The free character roster has been the same 6 characters for 9 months from me writing this review, the rouster is supposed to change weekly to let people try out the 18 characters before they buy them.All in all DON'T PLAY THIS GAME UNTILL UBER FIXES IT (which sadly will be never).

content:
Posted: October 6, 2014
												Since Steam had the gall to recc me this game in the new Steam Discovery update, I thought I'd write a review of the game in it's current state since it's abandonment. This game used to be GREAT. I bought Monday Night Combat a few months before Super MNC was released, and enjoyed a few hours of it but never got into it addictively. When Super MNC came out I was all over it. It was free2play, had a lot more options, characters, and got quite a bit of hype from a tie-in with Team Fortress 2 and one of the first games to incorporate Steam trading. It had a multitude of modes, a competitive but somewhat friendly community, and there were little to no problems besides a few occasional glitches to ruin the experience. Then the devs/publishers threw the community under the bus. They insisted while they were working on Planetary Annihilation that they'd continue support for this game, even if it meant just minor updates/champ rotation/fixes. But they outright lied, and never officially announced abandoning the game and left the cash shop open. The matchmaking is completely broken, there's some BS number in-game that states how many players are on, and the community is just a few random vets with complete newbies who have no idea the game is dead, with a huge gap of experience/character upgrades between these two groups.Uber is by no means a helpless small indie developer that doesn't have the resources to continue support for this game. Uber received over 2 million US dollars in Kickstarter money (with a project goal of 900k) for their new game, Planetary Annihilation, which has turned out into a slight disappointment in my opinion; although a few people in the Steam User Forums will insist the game's poor performance and their promise of offline -play is only because "they [Uber Entertainment] just needs more money/time". After receiving this large sum of money, Uber also charged $90 for alpha access to those who did not donate to their Kickstarter, and $50 for beta, all the while keeping silent on Super MNC and continuing to let it rot. This gives you an idea of Uber's recent shortcomings although you're free to look into them yourself and come to your own conclusions.Another recent Super MNC reccomendation writer stated that Uber has stated on their forums they have interest in reviving this game if "given the chance", but they've had plenty and I hope these are not empty words. I'd love to continue to convert friends back to this game, even if Uber didn't do content updates but fixed matchmaking and updated Pro rotation.

content:
Posted: January 3, 2014
												At this point in time, I cannot recommend this game to anyone.For starters, it has been abandoned by the creators.  The game revolves around a set of classes, or "pros".  Back in its heyday, the pros would be a free rotation, where 5-6 of them were free, a few of them were on sale, and the others were full price.  Since it was abandoned, the free pros haven't rotated at all.  This leaves you backed into a corner of hoping you enjoy one of the free pros, or spending money on a pro you have no idea you'll like.  Not that I recommend you even get that far.Secondly, the community is completely cannibalistic.  In higher population games, this isn't a problem.  This genre in particular (MOBAs), has quite an inclination to rage fits,♥♥♥♥♥♥talking, and general immaturity even more-so than you'll experience in Call of Duty.  Again, in higher populated communities, this isn't a big deal, you'll just move on to another game and have less than a .01% chance of running into the same jackass twice.  Well, SMNC has less than 200 active at peak times, and all the people playing this game are a rotating cast of alphas, betas, and pro players.  So if you like getting your♥♥♥♥♥kicked by the same pub stomp team over and over again, dive in!The chief game mode this was designed around doesn't even function anymore, due to low population/lack of interest from alpha/beta/pro players.  They would rather instant-gib you on the more deathmatch like "Turbocross" game mode.  There's a sick sense of enjoyment they get from stomping the ever living♥♥♥♥♥♥out of new players, regardless of the fact that this drives them away within an hour of play.  If you don't believe me, sit in on them while they converse on mumble, or spend a few minutes on the Uberent forums.So, if you like getting stomped, an impossible learning curve, horrendous population/matchmaking, and no further development from the company, this game is for you.  In its prime, SMNC was unique, fun, and had an awesome community to be a part of.  Calling it a shadow of it's former self would be an understatement.  A year or two ago, this game was a 5/5.  Now, it's a 1/5.  Tawokwww.GuildLeaders.com

Posted: December 16, 2013
												SMNC is a game I really want to recommend, but I cannot. While I have enjoyed this game for well over a hundred hours, the developers (Uber) are no longer creating content for the game. The source code has been given to someone outside the company who is not being paid for his work and therefore content patches are nearly non-existent. On top of this, there are still numerous issues within the game and the fact that the community is also nearly non-existent does not help; SMNC was quite popular at one point, but now since the dev's don't care and are working on another game (namely Planetary Annihilation) many players have obviously left for greener pastures, myself included. Overall, the IP has great character and I truly enjoyed my time with SMNC, however I cannot reccomend it any longer.

number of helpful: 21 of 22 people (95%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: July 20, 2016
												Well, after so many hours I can say without any hesitation that I know about 100% this game has to offer.I was there when it came out of beta, I saw it being developed, I saw it fall... slowly. It was and still is quite a ride. I know its history, I kinda know people who play, not personally, mostly in the arena and chat, all of them have unique play styles even those I despise. I just want to say "this game is awesome", but that just wouldn't be enough.So, without further delay.Super Monday Night Combat,  a third person blood sport arena shooter pact with adrenaline and excitement. Taking place in a distant future with 17 unique characters (pros) to choose from, all with unique skills and abilities. From slow and tanky to fast and slicy, thrown into one of the 5 arenas to fight for money and fame.Good things:The graphics are satisfying, with plenty of options to modify in your menu so even those coal running pcs can handle it.Sound, sound effects and music is clear, fun and spot on. The characters, their abilities, their weapons and map hazzards make unique sounds that are clear which is very important considering the fast pased gameplay. Even the announcers are helpful as they give you tips, inform you if something important happens or about to happen.Gameplay is fast paced and responsive as long you have at least decent connection.It has a tutorial level, training camp where you find basic information.No way to boost your gameplay performance with real money, you have to play and buy such items with in game currency, basicly no pay to win bs.Teamwork is encouraged.Bad things: The developers no longer support this game. The servers are up and not comming down any time soon as far as I know. Support with technical issues is still up too if you find yourself in troble with something. But the further game development has stopped.Population is low, still you find games in turbocross only which takes a few minutes at day time, but there aren't enough people for supercross or in general.A few bugs here and there but nothing critical, just annoying.Can't think of anything else bad. Nothing else bothers me.Conclusion:3rd person view team arena combat filled with fast paced gameplay. This game can be compared to Battleborn and Smite, but still has its own unique taste. It is free, easy to set up and get going, but hard to master. If you like something like that or would like to try, then this game is definitely for you..

content:
Posted: October 30, 2014
Super Monday Night Combat is an innovative, third-person arena shooter.Pros: Graphics, Sound, Controls, GameplayCons: CommunityFrom the sleek Assassin to the hulking Jackbot, the graphics look superb.  The music and sound mesh well with the gameplay, with the roaring crowd, gunfire, and cheeky advertisements.  A controller or a keyboard and mouse work very well.  Finally and above all else, Super Monday Night Combat is simply fun, standing out among numerous FPS clones and DotA-style mobas with unique and challenging mechanics.However, one simple flaw serves to demolish all fun to be had: the community has dwindled, leaving Super MNC's pick-up-and-play style a thing of the past.7/10

												Well I think it's safe to say the game is dead now, which is a shame because it's still one of the best MOBA's out there, and it's still a ton of fun if you can find a match with full teams. It's a shame the developer abandoned it, as it would still be alive and well if they didn't just bail for focus on Planetary Annihilation (I'm pretty sure they bailed on the initial build of that and "re-released" the same game for an additional cost for the initial buyers). Had they kept updating this, they likely would have had funds for future failures elsewhere, but they would have kept this gem and it's community alive. I recommend it because it was an awesome game, but you'll need to be patient with it if you want to find a match to play now.

content:
Posted: September 4, 2012
												This is a class based 3rd person shooter along the lines of a MOBA. I've given it a shot 3 times and really, it just failed to capture my interest like TF2 did. Its got quirky characters, a good art style and fun weapons, its just I'd rather be playing TF2. Like a MOBA game, there are bots on each map that allow you to level up your character so you can actually have a level advantage over other players on the map. So basically attack bots and avoid players until you get a level advantage to take out players all while collecting experience. Its a good system, it just made me want to play TF2. There is a lot of player customization too, which is nice, but eh.While I have only played 15 or so hours, I felt that spawn killing was far too common, because so many new fresh players come to Super MNC hoping to get TF2 hats that they don't understand how to play. A skilled player can just dominate an entire map and one player can overpower an entire team. The tutorial was pretty bad and I didn't really still didn't understand the game upon my 3rd time playing it. I feel a lot of people must not understand it, because there are players asking what they do or why the other 'players' are so dumb they walk into shots fired, when they don't understand the 'players' are bots, not actual humans.Really, just get your TF2 hats and get out or don't bother playing this game. TF2 is a superior game, but if you understand MOBAs and love 3rd person shooters. Then this game is totally for you.

content:
Posted: April 8, 2016
												Like almost everyone who plays this game, I came for the TF2 hats. And to be honest, I was pleasantly surprised at how fun it was. I especially liked the co-op mode, which is like MvM in TF2 except infinitely less stressful and more fun. In fact, the only reason (granted, quite a major reason) that I'm not giving it a thumbs-up is that it's essentially dead. Its developers have adandoned the project entirely, and the last time new content was added was about 3 years ago. That means that almost nobody's on, and the few that are tend to be salty tryhards that are too stubborn to admit the game is long dead. Valve, while not necessarily taking into consideration the desires of the community, constantly updates TF2, and for that reason it's more fun overall. My advice is to only download this game for the hats, and avoid spending money on taunts and cosmetics.

number of helpful: 10 of 10 people (100%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: December 17, 2016
												---Let's be fair: I am primarily just writing this "review" as a retrospective rather than "should I give money to this game"-essay.I'd say it's still worth writing this, so here goes:------Here are some bullet-points why I don't recommend this game:- You can only queue in a single queue at the time.Before the more or less accidental release from the closed-beta-phase, there was a time you could queue on all regions / servers / datacenters.Granted, there was only single game-mode also, the "SuperCrossfire".Had this been feature however re-added as they UberEnt wanted to, the queueing would have been a lot less of hassle.Here is a link with a  screenshot with "Ekanaut" himself more or less confirming they wanted to re-implement the feature:https://forums.uberent.com/threads/remove-region-player-counts.30497/#post-448477- Imbalanced "Meta"Primarily this goes to actual "meta"-things called "Products", since you cannot equip or otherwise buy & get inside battles itself (same things are with "Endorsement").To put it simply: There were a lot on Products / Passive-buff that either were for the most part really useless (especially the "Death & Respawn-effects" like "Snappy Comeback" that gave 30-seconds run-speed-buff every time you respawned; an very counter-productive-buffs you for the most part don't want to die at all in this game);and simply over-powered(E.G."Hot Hands" that has the base damage of 20-damage/second for 5-second-period to each enemy you grapple / grapples you every 10-seconds; only way you could semi-counter this as to either have a "pocket-medic"-team or using a product called "Asbestos" which in practice halved the burn-durations).((I may have some numbers slightly wrong. But point still stands some products were simply far too over-powerful...))Aside for the Death and respawn-products, these meta-buffs didn't have a counter / downside-effect (aside maybe for the Respawn + Death-products), so it was for the most part pointless to "not" carry all the three product-slots filled.- Exploits and generally UberEnt-folks endorsing thisRanging from far too easy spawn-point-camping (both player and bot / "minion"-spawns) to players going to out-of-reach-spots where they're for the most completely safe (especially flying to those places with character called "Assault".Biggest exploit being "turret / "tower"-cheesing", which means damage the turret out-of-the-reach or otherwise from angles the turrets cannot counter at all (primarily by "clipping" gun-models through walls or poking behind corners, since the turret / towers only aim the center the of the character-models).In all scenarios the developers for most part simply say "Git gud!", to summarize it best.Exploits itself probably described the "majority" of the players the best: If it helped them to win, they did it, always.Actually, the player-spawn points "deserve" its own section:The biggest flaw of it was that it only had three very narrow doorways (like you could barely fit two player-characters next to each other next to these, or maybe you couldn't at all (or at least this is how it seemed)).Due how narrow these doorways are, for the most part players inside the "spawn-dome" had pretty much zero-chances to fight back the campers outside, especially if there was extra walls nearby to hide behind ("Bullet Gorge"-arena being the worst offender of this by even allowing higher-ground vantage-points thanks to jump-pads!).And considering how really easily / abruptly the "primary"-mode ("SuperCrossfire") "snowballed", it was simply just horrid...---There are few things however that still makes me wish we could remake or otherwise revive this game:+ Replay-functionSure, it wasn't the most intuitive just like replay-systems generally are. But it's far more better than having no replay-system at all.+ Player-charactersDefinitely the biggest draw of the whole game was the character-roster. Pretty much everything is just right; just right; I really find anything that one could "improve"-about them (aside maybe related to following thing).And my goodness, the animation: Even in 2016 I've yet to see as perky or otherwise this good'&'smooth "cartoon" animation.Whoever people part of the animation-team(s), I really hope to see more games with these animation (styles?).I just wish they could have included rest / all of the old animations plus lines from the previous game ("Old" Monday Night Combat (1)) (mainly the lip-sync and such).+ World, Lore, WhatnotsIn semi-symbiosis with the character-roster is the world-building.From the arenas itself to announcer / commenter-talk / banter, this game certainly feels like a real universe instead of just a game with random characters that just happens to be there. I.E. the characters actually feel like having a genuine purpose there fighting / being gladiators in these arenas (I.E. to simply put: They're specifically constructed clones(?) fighting for the entertainment of people watching).Basically, for the most part I don't question at all why this all is happening (at least I don't; heck I'd be more than happy to watch sapient(?)-gorillas duking out with "Leonardo Da Vinci" all day, if I could that is).+ The gameplay-itself was actually goodExploits aside, the gameplay itself was really good.They could have made the gameplay-better by making the exploits not worth (E.G: making turrets take less damage the further you were away from them, alongside not pushing with bots / "minions").But otherwise the pacing, abilities / skills (aside maybe for the lack of "telegraphing" or other indicators / tell-tales), everything gameplay-wise was actually solid and really-really good,Best thing was of course that bot / "minion"-kills were shareable; as long as you kept damaging / "tagging" them, you had a chance to get a bot-kill thus level-up plus get money for in-battle-purchases.I personally think relating all damage to singular "damage-rating"-stats was actually quite clever.In case you'll more info what I am talking about, I have a quite detailed guide written about it:


Damage Rating 101 
A Guide for Super Monday Night Combat
By: Pave

			The Basics of Damage rating in SMNC and what does it do. The original more often updated version can be found at offcial forums of Uber Entertaiment.		


((I highly recommend reading the UberEnt-forum version too for more up-to-date / non-"link-rot"-version of the guide.))And of course, it was an actual 3-dimensional "Shooter MOBA" with Z-axis and such; jumping especially had a purpose (primarily to dodge ground-slam-shock-waves).------So yeah, Super Monday Night Combat "was" a good game at the base.But unfortunately the developers failed / were apparently not willing to to make this game more fair-and-square and fun to to play (true, fun is subjective thing).At least the players who got for the most part those who got spawn-camped, cheesed, or otherwise beaten due exploits for the most part more than likely didn't have fun.---------

												A great and funny game.Though this is free to play you have NO possibility to buy ingame advantages.You can use your steam wallet's cash to buy great looking armor and weapons. This stuff has no influence on your stats.You can also buy boosters but they are totally worthless and won't influence much. :-) So don't worry.This game is more about tactic than about going after kills. The more of the enemy bots you kill the faster you level up. 2nd is you shouldn't get killed. Third is: Destroy the enemy.If you are interested in this game, just try it. It is free anyway. Just one important thing:DO NOT START SUPER CROSSFIRE GAME MODE.Because of the small playerbase it will take forever to get a match at Super Crossfire. Just play TURBOCROSS. You will find matches even faster. Sometimes I have to exit the lobby and restart so I get a match after about 2 minutes. But that's really the worst case scenario.There are even some nice guides.

content:
Posted: December 1, 2013
												This is a great game, if you know what you're doing. Fast paced lane action, I think this combines FPS and MOBA almost flawlessly (with the exception of getting oneshot by the turrets :P) Learn each of the different classes (pros in this game) in the training zone BEFORE you play them in a ranked match. My personal favorite is probably the Assassin, despite how hard she is to play (i.e. bouncing off the walls to end up backstabbing someone.) Overall, tons of triggerhappy fun, free TF2 items, and humor that'll keep you laughing while on the edge of your seat. This is so much more fun with friends too! (Skype calls, you never fail to amuse me.)

content:
Posted: October 24, 2014
												A fast-paced third-perdon shooter. It's really fun. All game modes really focus on one central thing (which isn't bad.). Escorting robots to the enemy team's "moneyball" , whih is guarded by rocket turrents, and destroying it all, while defending your own. You pick a "pro" to fight as. They each have their own skills and pros and cons. You can upgrade your skills, as well as your offensive (more damage, etc.) and defensive (more speed, etc.) (for the match being) in the heat of battle. There's a mascot that contantly runs around dropping money (which can be used to buy powerups in battle) and health items, and juice. Get enough juice, you become overpowered for a short time.    Another reason to get this game is you can get two hats for Team Fortress 2.  Bad thing is the game is dead. The devs no longer update it or anything. But should you really care? No. Play it. It's worth while.

			here is the review for this game on steam http://steamcommunity.com/id/blinkdoggie/recommended/104700		

-note-outside blitz mode its best to ask in chat for a invite.A fps that plays like dota2. The main game consists of pushing lanes and taking out "towers" to get the the opponents money ball.You start each match at level 1 and can level upto 15 and on each level you can upgrade 1 of your 4 powers.As you play you will get money for bot & player kills.You use this money to activate turrets, jump pads, spawn bots, power-ups, Shelly (fires rockets in one side of the level damaging opponents) and a annihilator that will kill all the opposing teams bots.There is also a blitz mode where you try to defend a money ball through as many bot waves as you can.The game has many characters or pros for different play styles and it helps game play if teams don't have to many of the same kind of pro on a team.Sadly most that can get a game now just play blitz mode because of the rampant exploiting in the other modes.Another problem is the levels anyone starting fresh will get matched with high level players (do to low population) and they normally just beat the crap out of you wile trolling and calling you names.The game is no longer updated and there is even a glitch for opening an infinite about of treasure balls.it's a fun game but its in a sad place do to neglect.

content:
Posted: December 24, 2016
												Honestly would have been a great game if UberEnt didn't abandon it without warning.  This was the third-person DotA-esque experience before SMITE came out, the team shooter with unique hero abilities and shiz back when Overwatch was still just that super vague Project Titan.   Had a pathetically bad F2P setup though which is what really shot it in the foot.  Gameplay-wise none of the team-based/MOBA-ish shooters to come out so far have really tried to capture what SMNC and its predecessor (Monday Night Combat) did.   Really was a gem.  Too bad it was left to rot in maintenance mode when it could have been a huge name if it had a more competent team running its monetization model.

content:
Posted: June 28, 2014
												Unique looking and excelent graphics, unbalanced and not newbie-friendly gameplay.Some characters are overpowered.Complicated upgrade system (products, endorcements etc), complicated menu, NO kick voting in case a hacker joins the game or someone is abusing a glitch.All followed by an un-friendly community (Some players were reported multiple times but nothing happened, bullying problems ) and a very close community (Few people are online), sometimes servers are down.From my experience what I enjoyed the most are the graphics and the unique interaction between the player and the 3rd person shooter as well as the great animations.I would reccomend the game this game to someone who is characterised as "Gaming Pro" but definitely not to someone who has the same experience as I have ( low ).I really regret spending money on this game to buy new characters.Uber, on their try to make a new game with fancy graphics forgot that the gameplay matters as well.And not only that but they try to make people forget that this game is a rival of Monday Night Combat, by removing support ( But you still have to pay Monday Night Combat to play!"What I see is a company with great graphic skills to try desperately to make a new game to attract players.

content:
Posted: May 31, 2012
												If you're looking for something a bit out of the ordinary then you might want to check out Super Monday Night Combat, it's a MOBA game mixed with a 3rd person shooter and it works surprisingly well.The game looks good, has a great sense of humor, and the controls are responsive and easy to learn. The gameplay mainly centers around killing bots on a lane to escort your bots to turrets and eventually the opposite team's moneyball. Fairly straightforward, but it takes a few rounds to learn how things work. A lot of playable characters so there's sure to be someone who fits your playstyle, and they're adding more all the time.If you feel like trying something new, this is for you. Just be sure to play with some friends.

content:
Posted: March 9, 2014
												Super MNC is an TD like game with FPS elements and RPG. Maybe you can it also describe as a Moba. The aim is to destroy all robots of the other teams. For that you can built-up turret and uplevel them. Your character is important, too. You can choose Assassin, Supporters, Strikers or Assault. Many things in this game are fancy like gorillas as chars or to kill a chicken or the juicy boy. Guess that should be funny.But for Newbies it's a lot of distraction from the main game concept. The easiest mode is Blitz with 5 players destroying waves of robots. After round 20 it's getting nasty. Here can only the Pros survive. You'll gain a lot of XP here.The other mode is Crossstrike where 1vs1 to max 5vs5 can play. you have to check everytime the map and support your robot armys on their way to the other team's core. That makes fun.But for some reason you will get in this mode only about 10% XP of Blitz mode.That wouldn't be neccessary to explain, if you don't need the XP to equip you char with better endorsements. And though the game is F2P you can buy XP for real money 6500XP = $3. The prices are annoying. For a complete outfit you can pay $15. You should test it once and try to reach all achievements. In Daytime there are only 40 players inside ...

content:
Posted: January 11, 2015
												Unique game which is free ofc with mirco transactions that arent really micro however they do go on sale alot of times. This game is a fast pace third person moba game wahtever its called and its really fun. the background commentary is quite funny and sometimes quite useful. The background commentary also never repeat in my experiences. For low levels it is really hard to find matches meaning you have to make a customs matches with higher level people which mean you either lose horribly or get carried in most moba games. Another down note it has a lack of players meaning if you dont want to make a custom match with randoms and want to solo queue it will take about 30 mins+ for people level 1-19. Some positive notes the classes are balanced and none are really that OP however the diffcult pros are really weak if you dont know how to play the class. I find that once your under level you really cant catch up useless they become monkeys are lose the game on purpose.    IN CONCLUSION: This game is FUN as it is really unique to the games we currently have now. However mirco transactions are really pricy and lack new players. I recommend that they should add more customization and reduce prices on mirco transactions to somewhat a $1 USD for taunts and things. They should also improve matchmaking with randoms and make more servers cause they only have 3 regional servers Australia,North america and Europe. i recommend that people should pick this game up since it is Free.

												I guess I'll post a short piece: It's a MOBA done as a 3rd person shooter with a bit of character customization. The style of it is done as a futuristic televised arena. There's a vid on the store page that explains the gameplay, so I won't really get into the details here. I'm going to recommend the game because it is fun  - B U T - The game has lost a lot of momentum being 3 years old and getting players to stick around is going to be difficult. If they did, maybe it would draw more players in. Maybe. But then most people don't want to put that kind of effort into it when their game itch could be sated elsewhere. I'm only guessing that a lot of the recent negative reviews are sour because there's a lack of player base and having a healthy player base is really important for a game like this.

content:
Posted: October 4, 2014
												I played it to the point where I got the TF2 hats.  Didn't understand a thing.  After pouring time into Dota 2 and LoL, it makes a lot more sense.Certainly not bad, its a MOBA with third person shooter centric gameplay.  Even without knowing the basics of the MOBA genre, it was fun because "shoot the other color" is a pretty basic combat to grasp.  I'm pretty sure my teammates were raging at me because all I was doing was firing whatever explosive weapon I had at the bots and jumping around like an idiot, but every once in a while I got a kill or pressed that big middle button that made bots explode.  Even without understanding the in depth mechanics of the game, you can have fun if you can actually find a match.  My main issue is that there are a limited number of characters and it does the League thing of making only a select few available for free.

number of helpful: 5 of 7 people (71%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 3, 2014
												The Monday Night Combat series consists of two 3rd person mobas.If you need a refresher on what a 3rd person moba is, then go take a look at Smite.Smite is directly competing against other, big name mobas such as DOTA2 and League of Legends.What makes it special is the third person perspective.Super MNC brings a LOT to the moba table, but at the same time, leaves you with so little...While other mobas are all stuck in a self-perpetuating cyclone centering around the high fantasy artstyle, Monday Night Combat is sports themed. Thats right, kids. Sports. They even have commentators and sponsorshipsThe world of MNC is robust with many sound assets and nice, shiny icons. However, after a week or so of playing, its easy for any gamer to distinguish a clear lack of content.The "Pros" (otherwise known as "Heroes" or "Champions" in other mobas) all have their own unique abilities, weapons and roles making teamplay a very interesting and engaging experience. Fighting 5v5 alongside an army of lesser warriors to achieve a common, territorrial goal. Just like any other moba.The big difference that you will see after prolonged play in Super MNC, is the clear lack of pros. Big name mobas will release new characters once a month, on average. These competitors also sport enormous rosters, all tweaked for balance. Though I will argue MNC is balanced to some degree, there is no customization outside picking from a pool of limited characters. The downfall of this game is a clear lack of community involvement in light of the limited roster.Uber went into this with the best intentions, and for a while it was good. However, the moba genre takes an incredible amount of maintenance to keep things fresh. Especially in a market so competitive.If you liked this game, or want to see what a 3rd person moba can do, check out Smite. Otherwise hope on DOTA2.This game will always hold a special place in my heart. I bought the original, I played with friends. I made new friends. I laughed at many of the voices, and many of the gags in this game will always bring back warm feelings. The sad fact of the matter is that mobas cannot stand the test of time. When we look at it, every multiplayer game will eventually reach its demise.Farewell.

content:
Posted: January 19, 2015
												Pros:- Brilliant concept. The game presents itself as a future sport like The Running Man or Rollerball, leaning heavily towards the aesthetic of Smash TV.- Beautiful game in every way. A bit light on art assets, but what's there is gorgeous to look at and listen to.- Compelling Gameplay. The 3PS/DotA mix works much better here than the original Monday Night Combat. Metagame and strategy are equally important to shooter skills and teamwork.Balance: (not really a pro or a con)- The game is "fun". It's not really set up for competitive play. There are lots of random elements, such as bacon drops. Damage is slightly randomized. For most things this can be forgiven, but when your Jackbots can spit Bacon right into the enemy base, things get extremely crazy.- The cash shop. This is why the game is free to play, and also why the game never made money. The ecomony, while robust on paper, is infinitely exploitable via Steam Trading. The game needs to retain players to sustain the cash flow and - for the reasons listed below - that never happened.- Super Blitz mode is a decent way to farm Combat Credits and work on your PvE skills, but it will MELT YOUR FACE. It's impossible to win by design. The "goal" is to keep your Moneyball alive for as many waves as you can. You will fail eventually. You can buy tokens to repair your Moneyball and turrets during the round, but that's sort of cheating.Cons:- Matchmaking is completely broken. There is no "ranked queue". Everybody above level 20 gets thrown into one gigantic free-for-all and it sucks for new players. Newbs don't have flexible product loadouts or any endorsements (runes) worth mentioning. Combined with being generally unskilled at either the shooter or DotA elements or (god help you) both, newbs consistently get rekt every game until they can scrape together a decent understanding of the game mechanics and unlock most of the pros and products.- The Practice Game mode doesn't work. At all.- The tutorial is terrible, to the point of being arguably non-existent. The Training Camp is essentially a museum that showcases the various gameplay-related objects and lets you practice interacting with them to an extent. The ability to practice against Jackbots and Chickey Cantor in nice, but there isn't any particularly useful information to be found here, apart from what everything looks like and what each thing supposedly does.What I would suggest after touring the Training Camp is running a few solo Custom Games so you can at least figure out how lane bots spawn and why killing them is important. Then close SMNC and watch a few gameplay videos. Perhaps uninstall entirely. Your call, really.Turbocross is the only mode with decent queue times at the moment, and that's due to the drop-in/drop-out nature of the mode. Turbocross is rebalanced to play like old MNC, minimizing the importance of the DotA elements. If you're REALLY DESPERATE for Overwatch, you might enjoy killing time here.

content:
Posted: January 27, 2014
												This game could have been great but it has too many flaws to keep me interested after I win the second of two Team Fortress 2 promotional items. The tutorial isn’t even remotely helpful, the learning curve is insane, and there’s no way to learn how to play the Pros (the playable characters) without having to play with other people, who are almost always far more experienced than you. Matchmaking is the only real way of playing, but the problem with it is that you are pretty much guaranteed to wind up against people far out of your league and paired with new players who are just as confused as you are. You should learn to play with friends. That way, you won’t have to worry about people with freakish experience and you can help each other win the hats for TF2.

content:
Posted: October 9, 2014
												Best third-person DOTA style game out there, in my opinion.  It is free, with a free hero rotation.  You pretty much only pay for cosmetics.It is very funny, with lots of wacky characters, odd moments, and homorous "play-by-play" commentary.  Overall, I love this games style.  But don't let its light-hearted presentation fool you, SMNC can be quite the challenging game.It is unfortunate that any further developement has seemed to seize.  Uber seems to have abandoned SMNC to work on their crowdfunded project, Planetary Annhialation.  Hopefully with that project nearing completion (or so I think it is) we will begin to see updates to the game soon.  As of this date (10-9-14) the last update to SMNC was released on March 18th, 2013 (well over a year ago).

content:
Posted: June 30, 2014
Special note for TF2 players: Just get in, do the achievements to get the hats and get out.Do NOT buy this game nor its original and not free counterpart, Monday Night Combat.The developer, Uber Entertainment, has abandoned support for this game for more than a year; not officially, mind you, but dead silence on anything from the company on the MNC/SMNC front as they are concentrating support on another game of theirs.While this is a fun, balanced 3rd person MOBA, mixing Team Fortress 2 and DOTA, as well as being one of the few games that is not only ACTUALLY hilarious, unlike other games where the jokes are funny once and never again, this has such an extensive library of well-written lines, it is sad that the developer decided to sabotage the game for a quick buck via the F2P & in-game store model. Save your money.

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 10, 2014
												Essentially, SMNC is the perfect rip-off for tf2 due to the various classes they offer, and attempts of humor. Guns, blood, guns, chicks, more guns, weird red-headed (literally) dude who talks about weird♥♥♥♥♥♥ and of course more guns. Seems fun right? Only if you have high-processor, a gaming computer, and a something that will act as a blocker for anything off-screen that will slow your game. WHAT WAS THAT? SLOW? GAME? Yeah, it lags alot for most computers, and you usually have to adjust the options to the lower degrees and turn off optionable mechanics, which pretty ruins the game's look. It looks cool, what with all the tron-like outfits, space marine suits, and the colors available. The voices.........are ♥♥♥♥ing annoying. Some things are just random, though i can't say that's a complaint since it's heard in tf2 and borderlands 1 & 2 yet is very entertaining and likeable. But some of the things are just eeeeeeuuuuuuggggghhhhhhh. I don't want to really get into that. The music isn't really that enjoyable either for the majority of anyone who'll play it and not many people will since there's many other multiplayer shooters that are good like TF2, HL:DM, CS, Quake. Most people would play those games (or CoD ♥♥♥♥ing-whatever-edition) and usually a online shooter that works in thirdperson doesn't usually work very well, though many games have an option to select firstperson and thirdperson. In the end due to a lot of lag issues for pretty anyone, bad voices, and low amounts of true imagination and inspiration SMNC proves to everyone that maybe we need to really tighten the hose that's spraying multitudes of online shooters like Black Friday deals, and look at the shooters of old or the shooters of the newer gaming generation(s). Hell, maybe just play other genres of games (I'm kinda referring to CoD addicts right here), or you could just go outside, or (if you're old enough) go to a strip club! Actually I don't know about thew club, it'll probably be pretty dirty in ways you wouldn't enjoy and if you broguth a black light in there? ♥♥♥♥ me running. So there you go, SMNC is not worth the option-managing and playthroughs, not unless major updates come out that add new default looks, change some things around, and improve the quality of the game. Until then, we should just sing Kumbayah.

content:
Posted: November 25, 2016
The eye-opener for everyone:Okay guys, just let's be straigth now:This game has just has a lack of everything. The game itself is very onlogical, it doesn't look and feel familiar to as example TF2. It's a real pay to win game, if you have played this you really will know what pay to win means and never call a random game pay to win again. And what I just find very sad is that people spend lots of money to buy ingame goods and now the developers went this far that they have deleted everyone's inventory... Why? Its simple, they know that the game is dead. It is just a waste of time playing it guys, only a few people are playing this though, in a very boring gamemode. Don't think that you can download the game and later go play this. Almost all modes are dead and if you really want to play the one you like, the matchmaking servers will kill you because the download time of this game is just quicker than just playing a mode of the game. There is no real community. And everyone comes for the TF2 items. Listen up buddies, it's not worth it! Any idea how long it will take? Awkward controls, awkward third person, everything is just awkward in this game! So please guys don't play this nor get in touch with it, nor download it. Think about your children, your wife, the ones you care about! (This was just a little joke, don't take it very serious.) I also heard that the devs will maybe revive the game, or they are busy with another projects or maybe even a big one! If this is true, I will edit this review, but as how it's now I don't think this will happen... The last update of this game was in 2013 so yeah. Well, this was my review about this trashy game! I hope you enjoyed reading this!

content:
Posted: June 29, 2015
There's alot of things to be said..Gameplay Pros:Well, I enjoy the MOBA/Tower Defense style it has to it. Lots of scenery & colorful things to look at, easy to spot enemies, numerous buttons to press to activate certain things that'll slightly support your team! Unique classes as well, and to be honest, there is ALOT of Team Fortress 2 in there. But hey, that doesn't matter here. The gameplay is honestly easy to manage, very smooth.During PVP, its easy to get caught up in a fight when you're in a lane. But as I said earlier, it is extremely easy to spot enemies, they stand out so much - Which isn't always a bad thing.Gameplay Cons:Major M1 Attack bug, I'm sure this is known as well. If you fire a full round and it auto-reloads, the next round you fire will be non-existant until you have at-least 5 bullets left in the chamber. No damage will be done during that time, and it even does the firing animations/muzzle flashes!Horribly unbalanced! And for all the long-time players out there, you better agree on this too; Endorsements are a thing in this game - Basically gives you anything you can imagine, Attack Speed, Reload Speed, Attack Damage, Jump Height, Reduced Damage Received, the list goes on. Meaning, if you barely started this game and you enter a PVP match against someone who has at-least 40 hours in, you will get shredded.Soundtrack:I do enjoy the soundtrack in this game, just like the old Monday Night Combat it kept the genre of Rock. Otherwise it wouldn't of made sense..Although there is some conga music there..Voice Acting:The voice acting is good, could use some work here and there but for the most part, it's good! I grew tired of hearing the Annoucer's voice though, he's so damn annoying. If you lose a damn match, he'll jump on you for it. "OHOHOH, HAHA. I FEEL SO MUCH BETTER BECAUSE THESE GUYS..SUCK!"Conclusion:I played this game to Level 20 for a Team Fortress 2 hat, as much as I LOVE Monday Night Combat - Super Monday Night Combat was meh.6.5/10

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 4, 2012
												Though Super Monday Night Combat was once a fantastic game (and still is, in terms of gameplay), it was mishandled by UberEntertainment to the point where the game has little to no playerbase and is no longer being updated by developers at all.In it's prime, it was being updated every week with a rotation of free Pros to play as, new maps and characters were being added frequently, and lots of cool cosmetic options were being added over time for every character.  The game itself has fantastic visual design, wonderful voice acting, and animation that's second to none.  It's full of character, highly competitive, and blends the best parts of MOBA/ARTS style games with the gameplay of a 3rd person shooter.  Super Monday Night Combat was awesome, but those days are past and the only remaining players are all angry, bitter, anti-community folks that have nothing else left to play.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 12, 2012
												SMNC is best described as a fusion between Moba (DoTA) and FPS (TF2) genre's. Choose a Hero, join a team of 5, push creep wave's into enemies base, win game. First and foremost - this game is difficult - it's a full of FPS and if you start doing badly, by not killing enemy creeps etc, you will be lower level than enemy Hero's. And then they will eat your face. It's a game very high on teamwork. It's a game you have to sit down and give a while to learn, before it starts rewarding you with joyous victory. Stylistically, this game is one of the most lushest, comedic experiences I have come across, F2P or not. Each character is voiced differently, and the commentators who run throughout the game are both Awesome and incredibly varied. As a F2P game it should be noted that only vanity items cost any money, so feel free to give the game a go, if you feel that this is a genre you could enjoy. Highly, Highly recomended.

Though the only mdoe I have played is Super Blitz since I didn't find an interest in Team Deathmatch modes for this particular game.This game however does not get enough credit with it's corny lines and fast-paced action. Though I can only vouch for it's Super Blitz mode. Which pits 5 players of various player-chosen classes against hordes of robots while the announcer of Super MNC yells and cusses you out. So far I have only reached round 47, but the action is still incredibly fast and packed with bullets and explosives. A very fun play once in a while, otherwise it's very repetitive. Class customization allows you to boost your character how you want to, but not without it's side effects in the case of 'Endorsements'.I would say that if you have an interest in Team Fortress 2 or Gotham City Imposters, you should give this game a try as it's also Free-to-Play.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 12, 2012
												The game is decent-good, depending on your stance on hero seige (DOTA-model) and arcade FPS game. The game is quite a fun play however for most matches the classes are unbalanced terribly, with certain characters like Megabeth being independent of all allies/combination and thus making her somewhat broken for public matches. That being said the gameplay itself is about killing the opposing teams moneyball, which can be equivalent to the TFT or TToL in DOTA, where you push down lanes and kill the enemy.  The graphics are quite good based on the artstyle and game engine, however despite being pretty it is still largely inferior to other class based FPS games like TF2. The unlock system also keeps most classes locked until you either a) spend a reasonable amount of money or b) waste a large amount of time trying to get said clases, even performing well in every match, it would take about 20h to get the first unlock (this includes the 2-4 min search times for games). Good game, not great.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 5, 2014
												Barely playable MOBA. The matchmaking mixes players regardless of their level, resulting in unbalanced matches. The game only gives you 6 characters to choose from, the rest of them is locked behind a paywall (You want to purchase this guy? 7000 gold. Good luck. You only get like 50 for a won match). Needless to say, premium characters are way stronger than basic ones. The netcode is terrible as well. Often grappling your opponent doesn't register and the game tends to jitter because of lag.The game is REALLY slow paced. Everyone does a low amount of damage and has a lot of health, including bots/turrets. As a result, the rounds tend to drag on forever.The nail to the coffin for that game is its terrible community. If you ask for advice, you're bound to be patronized and insulted by elitist players. SMNC is a waste of time. The only reason you'd want to play this atrocity is because of 2 free TF2 hats earned by completing achievements.

content:
Posted: January 8, 2014
												It's a great game, but it's dead now. Matchmaking is bad because of the lack of players. Actually, most of the problems are caused by a lack of players. In terms of gameplay, it can be a bit hard to get into. You either really love it or really hate it. Besides a few passive stat buffs, there is no item building or anything like that, so the character you pick is locked to a specific role. A role you have either have to play a lot or research a lot to play well.However, SMNC makes up for the lack of character variance with its gameplay variance. Giant chickens, lightning strikes, dangerous robots, all accompanied by the best announcers you will ever hear. You will never play a game like this anywhere else. Not for free. It can be annoying sometimes, but the good far outweighs the bad.

content:
Posted: June 20, 2012
												This is a game, that i recomend. But the issue is, how can i recomend none existant gameplay? me and my friend played this back when supercross took 15~30 minutes for games, and we even survived the jump from noobie games to general games reletivly with ease, still fighting well and enjoying ourselves. The mountin of issues of this game didnt phase us, we wanted to see more, and we couldnt wait to see it improve.The developers Failed us and many others on a hardcore level that can only be rivaled by the likes of duke nukem and half life 3. i come back after some time and check the reviews and i find out that the game has been forgotton all about in favor for a game that in early access cost £60. That bieng the case, Super monday night combat now has broken ingame chat from what i read, inaccessability to modes that require que's. and has not recieved any new content or updates for too long.The game's fans have been ignored, let down, and forgotton about, a game that had potential to soar with popularity, earn the developers bucket loads of bucks, and grant its fans hours upon hours of mindless and intense fun. These hosts are in the wrong industry. Super monday night combat is a game i would recomend, and recomend again. If it ever returns with decent hosts.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 27, 2016
												As many past reviewers have said, if you are looking for an active multiplayer experience this game is not for you, as the player pase consits of less than 10 average players. HOWEVER, if you can get a bunch of friends together, you can still play this game and as a F2P title, I guess this could workout.However, if you are like me, and have a lack of friends, this game can still be fun if you like wave like defence games, with a slight tower defence element (more like money ball defence.)There are 3 main modes: Turbo Cross (dead) Crossfire (dead) and Blitz (sorta dead but you can solo play this at least.) As I stated above, I have no had the chance to play the crossfire & turbocross modes much as they player base is minimal, however I have played 1 game of Turbo Cross, and as a noob I will try to review these game modes. Turbo Cross consists of a very moba/dota 2 style of play, with PVP elements. Waves of bots (vreeps) spawn and push certain lanes towards the enemys money ball. You as a player have to push with your bots, destry enemy bots, and assist your bots in taking down enemy turrets. The team wins by destroying the oppositions Money Ball. Blitz takes the bots and pits them in increasingly difficult waves against you, where you/ your team must defend your money ball for as long as you can. Pretty much all my playtime on SMNC and MNC are from Blitz mode, as I really do personally enjoy wave like survival games, and the tower defence elements are so small and simplistic that I am not turned away from this. In conclusion, if you want a game to play with your mates, then I suggest picking this game up as it's F2P, however that is pretty much all this game can offer multiplayer wise at this stage unfortunately.

content:
Posted: September 23, 2014
												One of my favorite free to play titles!Do you enjoy class based shooters like Team Fortress 2 or Tribes Ascend? Do you enjoy MOBAs such as DOTA 2 or Smite etc? If you you said yes to either or both of those questions you owe it to yourself to give this game a shot. Right when you start they have an optional tutorial level where you can test out hero abilities, learn about the different AI controlled enemies (called creeps usually, bots in this case), and get a feel for the environmental weapons and events to help ease you into this hybrid style of game. Naturally a veteran of any of the previously mentioned games will want to skip over this, but you can leave the tutorial from the menu anytime so I recommend checking it out at least for the environment attacks.There is also a co-op horde mode which can be used for increased training before the real deal or as an alternative to regular matchmaking should you find high wait times* or have a more PvE minded team. It lacks the strategy of defending towers or spawning creeps, but is a good way to practice shooting, coordinating team abilities, or having absent minded fun. *Wait times are currently ridiculous in the 5v5 modes due to low player countSuper Crossfire is the name of the game's main entree. You only have two lanes and one jungle so team fights happen often and are never far away from you. One lane usually has 2 people and the other has 3, causing one of the lanes to be constantly pushed and therefore in need of defending. Alternatively you can have a fifth man roam between the lanes seeking the enemy roamer or hiding for surprise attacks. In the middle of all the fighting and pushing, events are constantly occurring in the jungle like a free money spawning "enemy", a Roshan like boss that gives a buff on defeat, a creep wiping laser and more. This gives the game a perpetual feeling of motion and speed never allowing boredom.There is another game mode which takes the premise of Super Crossfire and makes it more shooter-esque. Damage is increased, speed is increased, turret shields do NOT come back, health regen changes from DOTA-like to Halo-like, and other changes to creeps and players. This mode is great if you want a faster match or are less fond of the strategy layer.In Short:PROS+ Great Hero Variety+ Multiple Maps+ Multiple Modes+ Map Events+ Perfect Balance of Action and Strategy+ Excellent Humor with Top-Notch Voice Acting+ Amazing Art Style and GraphicsCONS- Long Matchmaking/No playerbase - game abandoned by devs. (The developers would like to revive it though)- What's left of the players are the most toxic of the community- No new content planned (heroes, maps, etc.) again due to abandonment- Matchmaking isn't separated by skill so new players can get destroyed by long time playersIf you can get 4 friends to try it with you a great game is waiting to be discovered even if you stick to the horde mode. If you can find 9 friends you've eliminated virtually all of the cons to this game.9.5/10

content:
Posted: February 16, 2012
												Anti-recommendation.This game is completely inaccessable for new players in any way, shape or form. The player base is primarily composed of hardcore players that spent hundreds of thousands of hours playing Monday Night Combat, as well as people that spend too much time playing MOBAs as well.Essentially you have a toxic envoirment for any new players; no one will "teach" you how to play and expect you to know how everything works from the get-go. The mechanics and even the controls aren't explained to you - I had to be told at least THREE DEGREES from friends that knew how to play that there was even a button to assign skill points!Just as well, there is no tutorial system whatsoever, there isn't a balance between setting players up that have barely started playing versus those who have hundreds of games under their belts, and all in all they seek to make the game less fun for newbies like me.If this gets out of beta safely it will be a marvel.
